Title: Bruno Mars
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bruno_Mars
Content: Peter Gene Hernandez (born October 8, 1985), known professionally as Bruno Mars, is an American singer, songwriter, musician, and record producer. Regarded as a pop icon, he is known for his three-octave tenor vocal range, live performances, retro showmanship, and musical versatility. He is accompanied by his band, the Hooligans. Raised in Honolulu, Mars gained recognition in Hawaii as a child for his impersonation of Elvis Presley, before moving to Los Angeles in 2003 to pursue a musical career.
Mars established his name in the music industry as a songwriter and co-founder of the production team the Smeezingtons. He rose to fame as a recording artist after featuring on the US number-one single "Nothin' on You" (2009) by B.o.B. Mars' first three studio albums‚ÄîDoo-Wops & Hooligans (2010), Unorthodox Jukebox (2012), and 24K Magic (2016)‚Äîfound critical and commercial success, with the lattermost winning the Grammy Award for Album of the Year. The albums spawned multiple international hit singles, including "Just the Way You Are", "Grenade", "The Lazy Song", "Locked Out of Heaven", "When I Was Your Man", "Treasure", "24K Magic", "That's What I Like", and "Finesse". He also featured on Mark Ronson's 2014 single "Uptown Funk", which became Billboard's best-performing song of the 2010s.
Mars' success continued throughout the 2020s. In 2021, he formed the musical superduo Silk Sonic with Anderson .Paak, and they released the 1970s R&B-inspired album An Evening with Silk Sonic, which contained the US number-one single "Leave the Door Open". Mars' 2024 chart-topping duets "Die with a Smile" with Lady Gaga and "Apt." with Ros√© spent a total of 30 weeks atop the Billboard Global 200.
Mars has sold over 150 million records worldwide, making him one of the best-selling music artists of all time. He has scored nine Billboard Hot 100 number-one singles. His 24K Magic World Tour (2017‚Äì2018) ranks among the highest-grossing tours in history. Mars' accolades include 16 Grammy Awards (including 3 Records of the Year and 2 Songs of the Year), 14 American Music Awards, 4 Brit Awards, 14 Soul Train Awards, and 8 Guinness World Records. He has been featured on Music Week's best-songwriters (2011) and Billboard's Greatest of All Time Artists (2019) lists, as well as the Time 100 and Forbes Celebrity 100 lists. Mars was the first artist with six RIAA diamond-certified songs and the first artist to surpass 150 million monthly listeners on Spotify.


== Life and career ==


=== 1985‚Äì2003: Early life and musical beginnings ===
Peter Gene Hernandez was born on October 8, 1985, in Honolulu, Hawaii, to Peter Hernandez and Bernadette San Pedro Bayot. He was raised in the Waikiki neighborhood of Honolulu. His father, originally from Brooklyn, New York, is of Puerto Rican and Ashkenazi Jewish descent, with ancestral roots in Hungary and Ukraine. His mother emigrated from the Philippines to Hawaii and was of Filipino and Spanish ancestry. Hernandez‚Äôs parents met while performing in a show‚Äîhis mother as a hula dancer and his father as a percussionist. At the age of two, he was nicknamed ‚ÄúBruno‚Äù by his father, who thought he resembled professional wrestler Bruno Sammartino.
Mars is one of six children and came from a musical family who exposed him to a diverse mix of musical genres, including rock and roll, reggae, hip hop, and rhythm and blues. His mother was a singer and a dancer and his father performed Little Richard's music, which inspired him as a young child. His uncle, an Elvis impersonator, encouraged the three-year-old Mars to perform songs by Presley and Michael Jackson. Mars began performing five days a week with his family's band (the Love Notes) at age four, including at the Sheraton Waikiki, and became known in Hawaii for his onstage impersonation of Elvis Presley. At one point, he urinated on himself during a performance of Presley's "Can't Help Falling in Love" when he was five; his parents thought they might be making a mistake, but he never wavered. Mars appeared in the Hawaiian tabloid shopper MidWeek as "Little Elvis" in 1990, and performed in the halftime show of the 1990 Aloha Bowl.
He had a cameo role in the 1992 film Honeymoon in Vegas, and was interviewed by Pauly Shore on MTV. When Mars was six years old, he appeared on The Arsenio Hall Show. He performed two shows a night throughout grade school with his family's band, covering Frankie Lymon and Little Anthony songs. The young Mars had a small drum set, guitar, piano and percussion instruments, and learned to play them. His parents divorced when he was 12 (ending the Love Notes), and his father's varied businesses failed. Mars, his brother and father lived in the "slums of Hawaii" in a car, on rooftops, and in a closed bird zoo (Paradise Park) where his father had worked. Mars changed schools and was bullied, but later became popular.
His Elvis impersonations had a major impact on his musical evolution and performing technique. Mars began playing guitar, inspired by American rock guitarist Jimi Hendrix. In 2010, he acknowledged his Hawaii-raised roots and musical family as an influence: "Growing up in Hawaii made me the man I am. I used to do a lot of shows in Hawaii with my father's band. Everybody in my family sings, everyone plays instruments ... I've just been surrounded by it." At President Theodore Roosevelt High School in Honolulu, Mars sang in a group (the School Boys) who opened for his father's new band with songs by the Isley Brothers and the Temptations. He became well known in local Hawaii entertainment in high school, opening for a large magic show and impersonating Michael Jackson for $75 per performance.
After his sister in Los Angeles played a demo of Mars for Mike Lynn (head of A&R at Dr. Dre's Aftermath Entertainment label), Lynn summoned Mars to Los Angeles. In 2003, shortly after graduating from high school, Mars pursued a musical career. He lived on Mansfield Avenue, and was surprised by its poverty and squalor. Mars adopted his stage name from his father's childhood nickname, adding "Mars" at the end: "I felt like I didn't have no pizzazz, and a lot of girls say I'm out of this world, so I was like I guess I'm from Mars." His stage name was also an effort to "avoid being stereotyped", since the music industry tried to pigeonhole him as another Latin artist and tried to convince him to sing in Spanish.


=== 2004‚Äì2008: Career beginnings ===
Mars said about moving to Los Angeles to pursue a musical career:

I'd always been a working musician in Hawaii and never had problems paying rent. And then it's like, "Now I'm in L.A. and my phone's getting shut off". That's when reality hit. I started DJing. I told this person I could DJ because they said they could pay me $75 cash under the table. I didn't know how to DJ. I lost that job pretty quick.
Mars signed a contract with Motown Records in 2004, but the deal "went nowhere" and he had a fruitless conversation with will.i.am's management. However, the singer's experience with Motown proved beneficial. After Mars was dropped by the label, less than a year later, he remained in Los Angeles and landed a 2005 music-publishing deal with record producers Steve Lindsey and Cameron Strang at Westside Independent. According to Strang, "Bruno came to the conclusion that the best way to further his career was writing and producing hit songs."
Lindsey showed Mars and fellow songwriters Brody Brown and Jeff Bhasker (whom Mars met through Mike Lynn) the ins and outs of writing pop music and acted as a mentor, helping them hone their craft. Bhasker explained that Lindsey would "mentor us, and kind of give us lectures as to what a hit pop song is, because you can have talent and music ability, but understanding what makes a hit pop song is a whole other discipline." According to Lindsey, he "held Mars back for five years while they learned an extensive catalog of hit music." Brown agreed in another interview. Mars played cover songs around Los Angeles in Sex Panther, a band with Bhasker and Eric Hernandez (Mars' brother, who became the drummer of the Hooligans).
When Philip Lawrence was told he should meet Mars, he was reluctant to do so since he did not have money for bus fare. Keith Harris, drummer for the Black Eyed Peas, told Lawrence: "Whatever it costs you to get out here, I'll reimburse you." Lawrence replied, "Just give me five dollars back for the bus." The pair began collaborating on songs for Mars, but received a number of rejections from record labels. Lawrence introduced Mars to Aaron Bay-Schuck, his future A&R manager at Atlantic Records, in 2006. After hearing him play a couple of songs on guitar, Bay-Schuck wanted to sign him immediately. It took about three years for Atlantic Records to sign Mars, however, because the label felt it was too early and he needed to develop as an artist.


=== 2008‚Äì2010: Production work and It's Better If You Don't Understand ===
Mars and Lawrence received a call in 2008 from Brandon Creed, who was seeking songs for a reunited Menudo. Creed liked their song "Lost", which was written for Mars, and bought it for $20,000. The sale enabled them to continue working, and Mars and Lawrence decided that they would write and produce songs for other artists. Eventually Creed became Mars' manager for nine years.
Mars was a music producer before becoming a successful solo artist, writing songs for Alexandra Burke, Adam Levine, Brandy, Sean Kingston, and K'naan. He said that the first "big hit" he and Lawrence wrote was the 2009 single, "Right Round", by Flo Rida: "That was our first taste of what could really happen with a hit we hundred-percented". Mars co-wrote the Sugababes's "Get Sexy" (2009) and provided backing vocals on their album, Sweet 7 (2010). He sang on the track "3D" on Far East Movement's second studio album, Animal (2009). Mars appeared on American pastor and hip hop artist Jaeson Ma's debut single, "Love", and American rapper Travie McCoy's "One at a Time" (a charity single for MTV's Staying Alive foundation) that year. He was recognized as a solo artist after appearing on American rapper B.o.B's "Nothin' on You" (2009) and McCoy's "Billionaire" (2010); both songs peaked in the top ten of several music charts, with the former topping the United States Billboard Hot 100 and the UK Singles Chart.
Mars said about the singles, "I think those songs weren't meant to be full-sung songs. If I'd sung all of 'Nothin' on You', it might've sounded like some '90s R&B." He released his debut extended play (EP), It's Better If You Don't Understand, on May 11, 2010. It peaked at number 99 on the US Billboard 200, and a music video was released for "The Other Side" with singer CeeLo Green and B.o.B. Mars and the Smeezingtons composed Green's successful 2010 single, "Fuck You".


=== 2010‚Äì2012: Doo-Wops and Hooligans ===

Mars released "Just the Way You Are" on July 20, 2010, as the lead single of his debut studio album, Doo-Wops & Hooligans, produced primarily by the Smeezingtons. It topped the charts of several countries, including Australia, Canada and the U.S. The album, released on October 5, 2010, debuted at number three on the Billboard 200 and topped the UK, Dutch and Canadian. Doo-Wops & Hooligans has sold 15.5 million copies worldwide. It spawned two other singles: "Grenade" (which topped the Billboard Hot 100, New Zealand, UK, and other charts) and "The Lazy Song", which topped the UK and Danish charts.
Other singles include "Talking to the Moon", which was released in Brazil and topped Billboard Brasil's Hot Pop Songs and Hot 100 Airplay charts. "Marry You" was released internationally and "Count On Me" was the album's final single in Australia. Mars released "It Will Rain" on The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn ‚Äì Part 1 film soundtrack (2011). The single reached number three in the U.S. and number two in New Zealand. Title: 24K Magic (album)
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/24K_Magic_(album)
Content: 24K Magic is the third studio album by the American singer-songwriter Bruno Mars. It was released by Atlantic Records on November 18, 2016. Mars reunited with Philip Lawrence and Christopher Brody Brown, who composed the album under their joint alias Shampoo Press & Curl. Mars enlisted new composers including the Stereotypes and James Fauntleroy. Recording sessions for 24K Magic took place between late 2015 and September 2016 at Glenwood Place Studios in Burbank, California.
Several critics said 24K Magic was crafted from elements of R&B, funk, pop, and new jack swing. Mars was inspired to create an album on which he could capture the sound of 1990s R&B, that he listened and danced to during his childhood. He wanted to make people dance and have the same enjoyment he had. The lyrics of 24K Magic explore themes similar to those of its predecessor, Unorthodox Jukebox (2012), including money and sex. According to Mars, although he was able to convince Atlantic Records of the album's sound, they were initially hesitant.
24K Magic debuted at number two on the Billboard 200 chart with first-week sales of 231,000 equivalent album units and became Mars's first number-one album on the US Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums. It also peaked at number two in Canada, France, and New Zealand, and produced five singles: "24K Magic", "That's What I Like", and "Finesse" (remix featuring Cardi B), which were commercially successful while "Versace on the Floor" charted moderately and "Chunky" had a limited release. "That's What I Like" reached number one on the Billboard Hot 100, becoming Mars's seventh number-one song in the United States, while "24K Magic" peaked at number one in New Zealand. The album sold five million units globally and was certified triple platinum by the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA), Music Canada (MC), and Recorded Music NZ (RMNZ).
Critical responses to 24K Magic were generally favorable; many reviewers noticed the change of style, focusing on contemporary R&B and the improvement on the production. Others criticized the detachment from the casual listener and the lack of "vulnerability" from his previous ballads. At the 2018 Grammy Awards 24K Magic won seven Grammy Awards, including Album of the Year and Best R&B Album, while the title track won Record of the Year and "That's What I Like" won Song of The Year at the same ceremony. Several publications listed the album as one of the best records of the year and the Associated Press named it as the tenth-best album of the 2010s. The album was also promoted through the 24K Magic World Tour (2017‚Äì2018), along with a number of television appearances.


== Background ==
In early 2014, Bruno Mars was interviewed by that's Shanghai and gave some details of a new album, stating, "I want to write better songs ... put on better shows ... make better music videos. I want my next album to be better than the first and the second." In September 2014, Mars tweeted, "Now it's time to start writing chapter 3", hinting that he was working on new music. Following the release of British-American musician Mark Ronson and Mars's single "Uptown Funk" (2014), Mars went to the studio to record more songs; he said he had no plans to release a new album "until it's done". Mars's new album was due in March 2016 but its release was postponed for several months because of his appearance at that year's Super Bowl half-time show. At the time, seven songs were already recorded. Mars worked with Canadian recording engineer Charles Moniz, who called the album the "next movement of Bruno" and confirmed the album was close to being finished in February 2016. Mars also worked with American musician Andrew Wyatt, who was involved in Mars's previous studio albums, and American bass guitarist Jamareo Artis, of The Hooligans, who said they had been "trying different ideas and experimenting" and "It's going to have a new sound ... the material is very groove-oriented". Mars also worked with American rapper Missy Elliott, but he said they were just hanging out.
In an interview with New Zealand radio DJ Zane Lowe for the Apple Music podcast Beats 1, Mars said the album is filled with 1990s influences. Mars concluded; "I just want to do music. I want to be the guy that brings joy to your life through his music." Mars affirmed he felt he was correct to record nine songs, saying; "If I can't pull you in with nine songs, I'm not gonna pull you in with nineteen!" He told that the album was inspired by a non-existent movie that he visualized. Mars said it featured "a Versace-wearing pimp" in New York during a summer night at the "baddest rooftop house party. 2:30 in the morning, the band comes out, fucking dipped in Versace. The girls are screaming." Mars stated this album contrasts with his others, on which he would experiment with genres: "I wanted to really hone it in and give myself a world in which I could keep it contained ... I want to sing more so than I did on the other albums". He chose to emulate "the feeling of the R&B he fell in love with as a kid", avoiding making it sound like a tribute or forced, taking inspiration from Jimmy Jam and Terry Lewis, New Edition, Bobby Brown, Jodeci, Boyz II Men, Teddy Riley, Mariah Carey and Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds. In November 2017, Mars was a guest on the Charlie Rose Show and said as he grew up pop music was "R&B-rooted songs", which he danced to at school balls and barbecues. Mars wanted to achieve the same "feeling and emotion", concluding "it was fun to dance, it was cool to smile on the dance floor with a girl and flirt with a girl on the dance floor". To achieve his aim to make people want to dance again, he needed the songs to make him dance. Mars was inspired by his passion "for R&B acts"; he said that was the feeling they wanted the album to have. He added, "it was all about the live show and the kind of party I want to throw".
Although Mars was able to convince Atlantic Records of the album's sound, they were initially hesitant. A private album listening party was held at Atlantic's offices in New York City for several journalists.


== Recording ==
Mars reunited with frequent collaborators, American songwriter, and producers, Philip Lawrence and Christopher Brody Brown, forming a new production trio, Shampoo Press & Curl, to record 24K Magic. It was recorded at Glenwood Place Studios in Burbank, California between the fall 2015 and September 2016. Nevertheless, the singer returned to the studio on the first week of October to complete the album. Mars revealed that he was not confident about returning to the studio after releasing "Uptown Funk" (2014) and was struggling to write new songs. On top of that, he added that it took him so long to create a song, he needed to "touch an instrument or it won't come out. If I'm not touching the guitar or touching the drum machine or playing the piano, the song just won't come out." He imposed a dress code in the studio during the recording process, favoring jewelry and "fine clothes" over sweatpants to create the "groovy, smooth and soulful songs" on the record.
Lawrence said, "We got the sitting in the studio laboring over songs for hours and days and weeks". He furthered that playing new songs live while recording helped. They noticed what was or not working and what it could be improved. "Finesse" underwent twenty different versions, including one in which Mars sang about "gold chains and cognac over a silky beat", and another which sounded "like a Seventies cop show". "Versace on the Floor" started with a "pi√±a colada vibe" before the beat was remixed, though, Mars felt his vocal performance and lyrics were not emotive enough for a ballad, and changed the melody and re-wrote the track. The singer-songwriter took a long time to write "Too Good to Say Goodbye". It was not complete until Babyface heard the chorus, encouraging the former to complete the song. They composed the song together on a piano. Mars used a flexatone, a percussion instrument, on the album, given to him by DJ Quik.

Mars asked American singer-songwriter James Fauntleroy to help him write "That's What I Like", but Fauntleroy end-up co-writing most of the songs on the album. Fauntleroy said; "Bruno is the core of those songs and Phil is a huge part of the reason those songs sound like that." He added that despite having a good time with them, it was "probably the most intense album process of my life". American record producer and DJ Skrillex said he and Mars were creating something "different, awesome and next level and sounds like nothing else that's happened before". He also affirmed that they could work on "more of a Skrillex thing". The song they were working on was not completed in time for the album's release. American rapper T-Pain who worked on "Straight Up & Down", said he saw Mars and his band, with the engineer "jamming out and having a good time". T-Pain affirmed Mars "was real specific about what he wanted".
The Stereotypes, a production team, were also involved in the album's composition. They have worked with Mars since 2007, however, after the singer signed a deal with Atlantic Records they did not collaborate very often. Nevertheless, in 2015, Jonathan Yip, a member of the Stereotypes, talked with Mars about working together. The latter asked for "some beats" for 24K Magic, but "nothing came of it". In June 2016, Mars asked Yip if they would like to help him finish a song for his album. He needed another song with a certain tempo and key. Yip sent Mars an idea that caught his attention, and he asked the Stereotypes to come to the studio. Once in the studio, it took them some time to "get the groove" on the track. They spent the first couple of hours catching up and having fun. The Stereotypes helped Mars finishing "24K Magic" and "That's What I Like". They also created "Finesse" with Shampoo Press & Curl. The team noticed that Mars "is his own biggest critic", a "perfectionist".
In August 2016, the album entered the mixing stage. Romanian-American mixing engineer Serban Ghenea had to return to his early career as an R&B and hip-hop engineer, to come up with the "esthetic" for 24K Magic. He explained, "the idea was to have a '90s R&B/hip-hop-influenced album, but with a modern sonic presentation". Moniz told they would felt great regarding a certain song and Mars wanted to "push it further" as he wanted 24K Magic to be "the foundation for his live show". The singer would ask to imagine the songs being performed live, to know their feeling and if they were danceable. The engineer confessed they would start to work in the afternoon and spent 14 hours in the studio each day, with the album taking 22 months to record and once the writing stopped, the singer would "bounce ideas around the room." He said Mars and his team were set to create an R&B album as "it's a part of who they are". Mars was close to the mixing process describing what he wanted for the album.


== Music and lyrics ==

24K Magic explores several genres, including, R&B, funk, pop, and new jack swing. Andy Kellman of AllMusic, thinks the album "might as well be considered the full-length sequel to "Uptown Funk"; Mars abandoned his previous new wave and reggae sound for an "all-out R&B" effort. The album includes the R&B ballads "Versace on the Floor", "Straight Up & Down" and "Too Good To Say Goodbye". "24K Magic", "Chunky" and "Perm" are funk tracks, while "Calling All My Lovelies" is an R&B heartbreaker song. 24K Magic also features new jack swing, hip-hop soul and funk on the tracks "Finesse" and "That's What I Like", with the latter also being an R&B song. Lyrics on the album are themed around money and sex.
The album opens with a talk box on "24K Magic"; the track's synthesizer riff and backbeat are inspired by "The Message" (1982) by Grandmaster Flash and the Furious Five. Title: Bonde do Brun√£o
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bonde_do_Brun%C3%A3o
Content: "Bonde do Brun√£o" is a song by American singer-songwriter Bruno Mars. It was official released on June 18, 2025, for digital download and streaming by The Smeezingtons under exclusive license to Atlantic Records. The single officially impacted Italian radio on the aforementioned date. The song was written by Mars alongside Jeremy Reeves, Jonathan Yip and Ray Romulus. It was produced by the former and the latter three as the Stereotypes, who also did programming. 
The track was supposed to only be used as a promotional tour song in Brazil, however, Mars's Instagram video that featured the song had more than 13 million likes, 2 million shares and 687 thousand comments beside various creations on TikTok and Reels. It eventually became the most watched video in his Instagram with 134 million views. At one point, Mars was chosen as the Fortnite Festival featured artist for Season 9. Mars thought the song would be a good fit for the video game and Fortnite agreed.
"Bonde do Brun√£o" is a Brazilian funk song performed in Portuguese. Lyrically, the song addresses Mars arrival in Brazil and because of that the party is now in Brazil. It received praise from publications, despite some accusations of cultural appropriation. The song not only pays homage to Brazil, but also draws inspiration and parodies "Cerol na M√£o" (2001) by Bonde do Tigr√£o. The official music video was directed by Daniel Ramos and released alongside the song, includes visual elements of the Brazilian culture intercuted with footage taken during Mars's tour in Brazil. Mars started to include verses of the song during his performance of "Perm" on his tour in Brazil.


== Background ==
On September 11, 2023, after performing two shows at The Town festival in S√£o Paulo, Mars posted a video on Instagram and Twitter. The track has a "funk beat" and repeats several times "Come to Brazil" and his nickname "Bruninho". One of the strong points of the singer's tribute was the use of the meme "como to Brazil". The video, which pays homage to Brazil and thanks the fans, was directed by Daniel Ramos. The song, titled "Bruninho's Theme Song", was produced by the Stereotypes with vocals by D'Mile. 
In the video Mars dances and walks in different streets in S√£o Paulo, including Pacaembu and Jardins, wearing a Brasil football jersey to a funk sound that says "Come To Brasil". It starts in the facade of a Childhood Education Center in the background, then it moves to the top of a building, which appears to have been shot in Hotel Fasano. It is followed with a graffiti in the background painted by street artist Eduardo Kobra. Next to the graffiti there are two steep staircases, that were recorded from different angles as Mars walks down. The video has footage from the shows with fans having fun and getting emotional.
In 2024, Mars performed in 15 shows in Brazil in five different cities and  "Bonde do Brun√£o" was used as part of the promotion for the shows. The song was first made available on Mars's TikTok profile after his shows in Brazil. The song became viral, with over 13 million likes, 2 million shares and 687 thousand comments beside various creations on TikTok and Reels. On November 25, 2024, it became the most watched video in Mars's instagram with 134 million views. 
The video starts with Mars getting a tattoo of Cristo Redentor in his chest, dancing Brazilian funk along with a community in Belo Horizonte and striking a pose with a Caramelo dog, a symbol of Brazil. The footage shows the singer in S√£o Paulo at a bar, Botequim De Primeira, in Vila Madalena drinking cacha√ßa and eating various snacks, including p√£o de queijo. The video also shows him hosting a party as a DJ, riding a motorcycle and includes footage of his shows in Brasil. The video ends with a final message "Eu te amo Brasil, Bruninho will return..." The footnote of the video said "Mais de um m√™s no Brasil e nunca mais serei o mesmo".


== Development ==
The idea of recording "Bonde do Brun√£o" arose during the last show of the tour in Brazil, in November 2024. At the time, Mars presented an improvisation of the song as a goodbye gift to Brazilian fans. The song went viral on various social platforms and fans asked for the official release of the track. 
Mars has first appeared on the Battle Royale of Fortnite as a part of Silk Sonic in 2021  The singer revealed that before the launch of the Festival Season 9 he didn't hesitated on collaborate again. Mars recalled that when they collaborated in 2021 there wasn't a Fortnite Festival, so he was eager to add more music. At one point, they decided the song would be a good fit for the game and Fortnite agreed. In June 2025, it was announced that he would appear as the Fortnite Festival featured artist for Season 9. This was also announced on his official website.


== Release ==
"Bonde do Brun√£o" was only as a promotional tour song. Mars explained that it was "a fun idea we put up on Instagram while I was in Brazil", but it "took a life of its own". The song was first previewed in November 2024. To commemorate Mars as the Fortnite Festival featured artist for Season 9, the full version of "Bonde do Brun√£o" officially premiered via Fortnite on June 18, 2025. On the same date, it was officially released in various countries via digital download and streaming by The Smeezingtons under exclusive license to Atlantic Records. It was only made available on Apple Music a day later. The song was sent to officially impact Italian radio stations on the aforementioned date by Warner Music Italy.  The art cover features the outline of the Brazilian country with green and yellow colors as a tribute to the country.


== Composition ==
"Bonde do Brun√£o" is a Brazilian funk song performed in Portuguese. Lyrically, the addresses Mars arrival in Brazil and because of that the party is now in Brazil. The song not only pays homage to Brazil, but also draws inspiration and parodies "Cerol na M√£o" (2001) by Bonde do Tigr√£o. "Bonde do Brun√£o" is an energetic parody of the aforementioned song and also an homage to Brazilian funk, including slang and music. The singer adapted his vocals to the Brazilian funk style and also used various Brazilian catchphrases to get closer to the targeted audience. 
"Bonde do Brun√£o" was written by Mars, Johnathan Yip, Ray Romulus and Jeremy Reeves. It was produced by the former and the latter three as the Stereotypes, who also did programming. Yip was in charge of the percussion, Romulus played the synthesizer, while Reeves played the bass and also served as the mix and mastering engineer. Charles Moniz was the recording engineer. The song's production included several Brazilian music professionals to assure the song's authenticity.


== Reception ==
"Bonde do Brun√£o" received positive reviews from publications. O Antagonista affirmed the release of the song symbolizes a bond, celebrating cultural diversity and the exchange of different music styles. The publication, Terra, mentioned the track shows irreverence, respect and authenticity. A combo that has been prevalent on the artist's career. They added that when there is "authentic" and "respect" the mix of culture can produce unexpected results. Mars didn't only released a song. He created a bridge between worlds, celebrating Brazil with humor, rithm and "muito gingado". The latter publication, mentioned the release of "Bonde Do Brun√£o", Mars became one of the few international artists that sings a song in Portuguese and dives in the Brazilian culture. This song reveals the trend of music globalization and that language and cultural barriers are overcome through art. 
Mars was accused of cultural appropriation. Nevertheless, others praised Mars for paying tribute as he "celebrates the roots of Rio funk by interpreting verses and melodies typical of this musical genre". The singer also parodies with "the use of humor demonstrate the intention to play with the original theme, redefining its message." It is also seen as a collaboration despite being produced by foreign artists as it displays "respect and recognition for Brazilian culture."


== Fortnite Festival and live performances ==
Fortnite included an emote of Mars inspired on the dance of "Bonde do Brun√£o" and skin titled "Estilo Bruninho" with a yellow and green t-shirt inspired on the one he used on his Instagram post. On the game, Mars transforms into a playable avatar with a skin based on the song. topics.title: Early life and musical beginnings
summary_points: Born Peter Gene Hernandez (Oct 8, 1985) in Honolulu, Hawaii; raised in a musical family exposed to rock, reggae, hip hop and R&B which shaped his multi-genre fluency and stagecraft.
Early public performing began at age 3‚Äì4 as an Elvis impersonator with the family's band (the Love Notes); he performed regularly at hotels and local events, earning local recognition.
Developed multi-instrument skills (guitar, piano, percussion, drums) during childhood; impersonations of Elvis and Michael Jackson strongly influenced his vocal delivery and showmanship.
Experienced family instability (parents divorced; periods of economic hardship) that intersected with sustained performance practice through adolescence.
Moved to Los Angeles in 2003 after high school to pursue a professional music career and adopted the stage name Bruno Mars to avoid stereotyping and create a distinct persona.

subtopics.title: Childhood performance and influences
summary_points: Family performances at Waikiki venues and televised appearances (e.g., The Arsenio Hall Show) built early stage experience and confidence.
Impersonations of Elvis Presley and Michael Jackson informed his retro showmanship, choreography, and vocal phrasing.
Exposure to multiple genres at home (father's Little Richard influence; mother's singing/dancing) produced a broad stylistic palette foundational to later genre-blending.

subtopics.title: Relocation to Los Angeles and early career struggles
summary_points: Relocated to L.A. in 2003; faced financial hardships and performed various jobs (e.g., DJing) while networking in the industry.
Brief Motown Records contract (2004) that did not yield releases; later secured a 2005 music-publishing deal that pivoted him towards songwriting and production.
Met key collaborators (Brody Brown, Jeff Bhasker, Philip Lawrence) and formed early bands (Sex Panther), laying groundwork for the Smeezingtons and future production work.

topics.title: Songwriting and production career (Smeezingtons & beyond)
summary_points: Established a reputation as a songwriter/producer before solo breakout; co-founded the Smeezingtons production team with Philip Lawrence and Ari Levine.
Wrote/produced for other artists (Flo Rida's 'Right Round', Alexandra Burke, Brandy, K'naan, Sugababes) which provided industry credibility and financial runway.
Co-wrote and was featured on high-profile early hits‚ÄîB.o.B.'s 'Nothin' on You' (2009) and Travie McCoy's 'Billionaire' (2010)‚Äîthat increased his visibility as a solo artist.
Songwriting approach emphasized learning pop-song construction (mentorship under Steve Lindsey) and catalog study to craft commercially effective hooks and structures.

subtopics.title: Smeezingtons and production methods
summary_points: Smeezingtons combined Mars's multi-instrumentalism with collaborators' production techniques to produce polished pop/R&B tracks.
Mentorship and disciplined catalog study (guided by Steve Lindsey) were critical: the team practiced writing and reverse-engineering hits to internalize what makes successful pop songs.
Mars's production role ranged from instrumentation and vocal arrangement to co-writing, with an emphasis on creating live-show-friendly arrangements.

subtopics.title: Writing for others and breakout features
summary_points: 'Right Round' (Flo Rida) and other outside cuts provided the team's first major commercial success, validating their pop-writing approach.
Features on 'Nothin' on You' and 'Billionaire' served as Mars's mainstream introduction, demonstrating his ability to deliver memorable melodic hooks in guest spots.
Revenue and recognition from production/writing enabled Mars to fund his own recordings and secure later label support for his solo artist rollout.

topics.title: Major studio albums and musical evolution
summary_points: Mars's first three studio albums‚ÄîDoo-Wops & Hooligans (2010), Unorthodox Jukebox (2012), and 24K Magic (2016)‚Äîmarked distinct stylistic phases, each commercially successful and influential.
He blends retro influences (R&B, funk, soul, new jack swing) with contemporary pop production and emphasizes live-band arrangements and showmanship across albums.

Collaborative production models evolved: early work dominated by Smeezingtons; later records (notably 24K Magic) credited Shampoo Press & Curl plus other producers (the Stereotypes, James Fauntleroy).

subtopics.title: Doo-Wops & Hooligans (2010)
summary_points: Debut album that established Mars as a solo star; lead singles 'Just the Way You Are' and 'Grenade' reached global top chart positions.
Album combined pop balladry and upbeat tracks, sold approximately 15.5 million copies worldwide and produced multiple international hits ('The Lazy Song', 'Marry You').
The record's success was anchored by Mars's vocal range, melodic songwriting, and accessible production that balanced retro and modern sensibilities.

subtopics.title: Unorthodox Jukebox (2012)
summary_points: Sophomore LP expanded stylistic range into rock, disco, and R&B; spawned hits such as 'Locked Out of Heaven' and 'When I Was Your Man' and continued Mars's chart run.
Further solidified Mars's reputation for genre versatility and songwriting craft, positioning him for larger-scale productions and collaborations.

subtopics.title: 24K Magic (2016): concept, recording, and reception
summary_points: Third studio album heavily influenced by 1990s R&B, funk and new jack swing; concept built around a stylized party/rooftop nightlife narrative Mars visualized as a 'non-existent movie'.

Recorded 2015‚Äì2016 at Glenwood Place Studios; produced by Shampoo Press & Curl with contributions from the Stereotypes and James Fauntleroy; recording emphasized groove, live-band feel, and careful mixing to evoke '90s aesthetic with modern clarity.
Singles included '24K Magic', 'That's What I Like' (Billboard Hot 100 No.1), and 'Finesse' (remix with Cardi B); album debuted at No.2 on Billboard 200 and sold ~5 million units worldwide.

24K Magic received generally favorable reviews for its production and throwback sound, but some critics noted less vulnerability compared to earlier ballads; it won seven Grammy Awards including Album of the Year and Best R&B Album.

topics.title: Singles, chart performance and signature hits
summary_points: Mars has achieved multiple global hits across his career, with at least nine Billboard Hot 100 number-one singles and numerous international chart-toppers.
Signature singles include 'Just the Way You Are', 'Grenade', 'Locked Out of Heaven', 'When I Was Your Man', 'Treasure', '24K Magic', and 'That's What I Like'.
High-profile collaborations amplified reach: featured on Mark Ronson's 'Uptown Funk' (2014), which became Billboard's best-performing song of the 2010s, and later fronted Silk Sonic compositions.
Mars was the first artist with six RIAA diamond-certified songs and achieved significant streaming milestones (e.g., surpassing 150 million monthly Spotify listeners at one point).

subtopics.title: Notable collaborations and features
summary_points: 'Nothin' on You' (B.o.B) and 'Billionaire' (Travie McCoy) were early breakout features that introduced Mars's melodic voice to a wide audience.
'Uptown Funk' (Mark Ronson ft. Bruno Mars) became a cultural phenomenon and helped bridge retro-funk aesthetics with mainstream pop dominance.
Collaborations continued into the 2020s with Silk Sonic (Anderson .Paak) and duet singles (e.g., 2024 pairings) that extended his chart presence.

topics.title: Live performance, touring and The Hooligans
summary_points: Mars's live identity is central to his career: three-octave tenor range, retro showmanship, and a backing band (The Hooligans) that reproduces his multi-genre sound in concert.
Major televised and spectacle performances include the Super Bowl halftime show (2016) which expanded his global profile and led to a delayed 24K Magic release.
The 24K Magic World Tour (2017‚Äì2018) was one of the highest-grossing tours, demonstrating his capacity to translate record sales into large-scale live revenue and fan engagement.

subtopics.title: Tour production and commercial impact
summary_points: Mars emphasizes choreography, wardrobe, and band musicianship to create immersive, dance-driven performances reflecting the eras his music draws from.
24K Magic World Tour ranked among the top-grossing global tours and reinforced Mars's reputation for tightly produced, high-energy shows that appeal across demographics.

topics.title: Silk Sonic and recent collaborative projects
summary_points: In 2021 Mars formed Silk Sonic with Anderson .Paak; the collaboration produced An Evening with Silk Sonic, a 1970s R&B-inspired album including the US No.1 single 'Leave the Door Open'.
Silk Sonic emphasized period-authentic production, tight vocal harmonies and retro instrumentation, aligning with Mars's ongoing interest in vintage R&B aesthetics.
Collaborative projects have allowed Mars to explore narrower genre frames (e.g., 1970s soul with Silk Sonic) while maintaining mainstream commercial success.

subtopics.title: Artistic rationale and outcomes
summary_points: Silk Sonic allowed both artists to foreground duet-led soul performance, showcase instrumental flourishes and live interplay, and achieve critical and commercial acclaim.
The project reinforced Mars's brand as a curator/performer of retro-rooted pop, expanding his discography beyond solo-led albums into collaborative, era-specific works.

topics.title: Engagement with Brazil and 'Bonde do Brun√£o' (2024‚Äì2025)
summary_points: 'Bonde do Brun√£o' (released June 18, 2025) is a Portuguese-language Brazilian funk-inspired track that originated as a tour improvisation in Brazil and went viral on social media.

The song was produced with the Stereotypes and incorporated Brazilian musicians and cultural references; it was used in promotion for his Brazil shows and selected for Fortnite Festival Season 9 integration.

Reception was mixed-to-positive: praised for homage and cultural exchange by some outlets, while others raised cultural appropriation concerns; it produced tangible local impact (increased tourism and commercial interest for featured venues).

subtopics.title: Development, composition, release and impact
summary_points: Started as an Instagram/tour improvisation in S√£o Paulo and evolved into a full single after viral social media traction (millions of likes/views), official release via Atlantic/Smeezingtons, and inclusion in Fortnite.

Musically, the track adapts Mars's vocals to Brazilian funk cadences, uses Portuguese slang and references, and parodies/tributes elements of Brazilian funk classics while involving Brazilian production professionals for authenticity.

Release strategy combined digital platforms (Instagram, TikTok) and gaming tie-ins (Fortnite Festival); live performances incorporated lines from the song into existing setlists, enhancing local audience engagement.
Local impacts included media commentary on cultural exchange, increased commercial interest for locations featured in the music video, and charitable engagements tied to his Brazil concerts.

topics.title: Commercial success, awards and legacy
summary_points: Mars has sold over 150 million records worldwide, positioning him among the best-selling music artists of all time.

Accolades include 16 Grammy Awards (including multiple Records of the Year and Songs of the Year), 14 American Music Awards, 4 Brit Awards, numerous Soul Train Awards, and several Guinness World Records.
Notable milestones: first artist with six RIAA diamond-certified songs and first to surpass 150 million monthly Spotify listeners; inclusion in Time 100 and Forbes Celebrity 100 lists.

His commercial achievements are accompanied by consistent critical recognition for songwriting, production craft, and live-show design, cementing a legacy as a contemporary pop/R&B curator and showman.

subtopics.title: Awards and industry recognition
summary_points: 24K Magic (2016) won Album of the Year at the Grammys and the project received multiple high-profile awards reinforcing Mars's industry standing.
Recognition spans sales-based honors (RIAA diamond certifications) and editorial lists (Billboard Greatest of All Time Artists), indicating cross-measure validation of influence.

knowledge.abstract: This structured knowledge base synthesizes Bruno Mars's music career using three primary Wikipedia documents covering his biography, the 24K Magic album, and the Brazil-focused single 'Bonde do Brun√£o'. It captures Mars's development from a child performer in Honolulu to an internationally successful singer-songwriter-producer. Key methods in his career include disciplined songwriting apprenticeship, collaborative production teams (Smeezingtons; Shampoo Press & Curl), and a deliberate retro-modern aesthetic that channels R&B, funk, soul and new jack swing. Major milestones are documented: breakthrough features ('Nothin' on You', 'Billionaire'), the debut album Doo-Wops & Hooligans (2010), stylistic expansion on Unorthodox Jukebox (2012), and the concept-driven 24K Magic (2016) which prioritized groove-based, danceable arrangements and won multiple Grammys including Album of the Year. The summary also covers Mars's live performance ethos (The Hooligans, Super Bowl, 24K Magic World Tour), collaborative projects (Silk Sonic), commercial metrics (150+ million records sold, diamond certifications, streaming milestones), and recent culturally specific outreach exemplified by 'Bonde do Brun√£o'‚Äîa Portuguese-language Brazilian funk tribute that leveraged social media virality and gaming partnership (Fortnite). Across topics, the synthesis emphasizes Mars's hybrid role as performer, songwriter and producer, his consistent commercial success, and his practice of marrying era-authentic production with contemporary pop sensibilities to sustain broad popular and industry acclaim.
knowledge.conclusion: Bruno Mars's music career is defined by early immersion in live performance, disciplined songwriting and production craft, and a purposeful revivalist approach that blends vintage R&B/funk aesthetics with contemporary pop. His trajectory‚Äîfrom behind-the-scenes songwriter to multi-platinum solo artist and collaborative projects like Silk Sonic‚Äîdemonstrates versatility in studio production, performance, and audience engagement. Commercial milestones (over 150 million records sold, multiple No.1 singles, high-grossing tours) and critical recognition (numerous Grammys and industry honors) affirm his impact. Recent work, including localized, culturally engaged releases like 'Bonde do Brun√£o', shows an ongoing strategy of direct fan interaction, cross-cultural collaboration, and multimedia promotion, reinforcing his role as a global pop/R&B curator and enduring live entertainer.

report_parts:
## Early life and musical beginnings

Peter Gene Hernandez was born on October 8, 1985, in Honolulu, Hawaii, into a musical family whose eclectic tastes included rock, reggae, hip hop, and R&B, a milieu that shaped his later multi-genre fluency and stagecraft [1]. From an early age he performed publicly as part of the family's act, adopting an Elvis impersonator persona at approximately three to four years old and appearing regularly at hotels and local events, which earned him early local recognition and practical experience onstage [1]. During childhood he developed skills on multiple instruments, including guitar, piano, percussion, and drums, while his vocal delivery and showmanship were strongly influenced by impersonations of Elvis Presley and Michael Jackson [1]. Family instability, including his parents' divorce and periods of economic hardship, intersected with sustained performance practice through adolescence and informed both his resilience and continued engagement with music [1]. After finishing high school he relocated to Los Angeles in 2003 to pursue a professional music career and adopted the stage name Bruno Mars to avoid stereotyping and to create a distinct public persona [1].

### Childhood performance and influences

The formative years of Hernandez's performance career were rooted in family shows at Waikiki venues and in televised appearances, which together provided structured opportunities to build stage experience and confidence from a young age [1]. His early work as an Elvis Presley impersonator and later homage to Michael Jackson informed a retro-oriented showmanship that included choreography and particular vocal phrasing, elements that would reappear in his professional performances [1]. At home he was exposed to a broad array of musical styles‚Äîhis father's admiration for Little Richard and his mother's singing and dancing, among other influences‚Äîproducing a wide stylistic palette that became foundational for his later genre-blending approach [1].

### Relocation to Los Angeles and early career struggles

Upon relocating to Los Angeles in 2003, Hernandez encountered financial hardships and supplemented his pursuits with various jobs, such as DJing, while actively networking within the music industry [1]. He experienced a brief recording contract with Motown Records in 2004 that did not result in released material, after which a 2005 music-publishing deal shifted his trajectory toward songwriting and production work [1]. During this period he met key collaborators‚ÄîBrody Brown, Jeff Bhasker, and Philip Lawrence‚Äîand participated in early bands such as Sex Panther; these associations laid the groundwork for the formation of the Smeezingtons and his subsequent production and songwriting career [1].

## Songwriting and production career (Smeezingtons & beyond)

Before his breakout as a solo artist, he established a reputation as a songwriter and producer and co-founded the production team the Smeezingtons with Philip Lawrence and Ari Levine [1, 2]. This production work included writing and producing for a range of other artists‚Äîamong them Flo Rida ('Right Round'), Alexandra Burke, Brandy, K'naan, and Sugababes‚Äîwhich both validated the team's approach to pop songwriting and provided industry credibility as well as financial runway for subsequent solo efforts [1]. He also co-wrote and was featured on high-profile early hits such as B.o.B.'s "Nothin' on You" (2009) and Travie McCoy's "Billionaire" (2010), appearances that substantially increased his visibility as a solo artist [1]. Central to this period was a songwriting approach that emphasized deliberate study of pop-song construction through mentorship under Steve Lindsey and disciplined catalog analysis to craft commercially effective hooks and structures [1, 2].

### Smeezingtons and production methods

The Smeezingtons' production method combined his multi-instrumental abilities with the complementary production techniques of his collaborators to create polished pop and R&B tracks [1, 2]. This collaboration produced arrangements that balanced live instrumentation and contemporary production practices, with attention to clarity and mainstream appeal [1, 2]. Mentorship and disciplined catalog study under guidance from Steve Lindsey formed a core part of the team's creative practice; the team regularly practiced writing and reverse-engineering successful hits to internalize the structures and devices that make pop songs effective [1, 2]. Within this framework, his role encompassed instrumentation, vocal arrangement, and co-writing, with an emphasis on crafting arrangements that would translate effectively to live performance [1, 2].

### Writing for others and breakout features

Early outside cuts such as Flo Rida's "Right Round" represented the team's first major commercial successes and served to validate their pop-writing methodology in the marketplace [1]. These placements for other artists established the Smeezingtons' reputation and brought tangible commercial returns that supported further work and investment in solo projects [1]. His featured appearances on B.o.B.'s "Nothin' on You" and Travie McCoy's "Billionaire" functioned as mainstream introductions for his vocal and melodic work, demonstrating his capacity to deliver memorable hooks in guest roles and raising his profile among a broader audience [1]. The revenue and recognition produced by this body of production and songwriting work enabled him to fund his own recordings and to secure later label support for his rollout as a solo artist [1].

## Major studio albums and musical evolution

Bruno Mars's first three studio albums‚ÄîDoo-Wops & Hooligans (2010), Unorthodox Jukebox (2012), and 24K Magic (2016)‚Äîrepresent distinct stylistic phases in his recorded output, each achieving substantial commercial success and exerting influence on contemporary pop and R&B trends [1, 2]. Across these records Mars consistently blended retro influences drawn from R&B, funk, soul, and new jack swing with contemporary pop production techniques, creating a sound that honored earlier popular music forms while remaining radio-friendly and modern [1, 2]. This synthesis is paired with an emphasis on live-band arrangements and showmanship, a through-line in both studio presentation and the artist‚Äôs larger performance aesthetic [1, 2].

Concurrently, Mars‚Äôs collaborative production model evolved over this period. His early work was largely shaped by the Smeezingtons, a production collective that dominated the sound and songwriting on his initial releases, while later projects‚Äîmost notably 24K Magic‚Äîwere credited primarily to Shampoo Press & Curl with additional contributions from producers such as the Stereotypes and James Fauntleroy, reflecting a shift toward broader collaborative arrangements and more specialized production inputs [1, 2]. This evolution in production personnel accompanied deliberate aesthetic shifts between albums, with each record articulating its own thematic and sonic identity while maintaining continuity through Mars‚Äôs vocal presence and melodic sensibility [1, 2].

### Doo-Wops & Hooligans (2010)

Doo-Wops & Hooligans served as Bruno Mars‚Äôs debut solo album and established him as a commercial and chart-topping artist, led by major singles such as "Just the Way You Are" and "Grenade," both of which reached top positions on global charts [1]. The album juxtaposed pop balladry with upbeat, accessible tracks, yielding multiple international hits including "The Lazy Song" and "Marry You," and thereby demonstrating a capacity for broad commercial appeal across tempos and styles [1].

The record‚Äôs commercial impact was substantial, with approximately 15.5 million copies sold worldwide, a figure that underscores its global reach and enduring popularity [1]. Critical and popular recognition of the album centered on Mars‚Äôs vocal range, melodic songwriting, and production that balanced retro sensibilities with contemporary polish, qualities that anchored the album‚Äôs successes and established the artistic template he would develop in subsequent releases [1].

### Unorthodox Jukebox (2012)

Unorthodox Jukebox expanded Mars‚Äôs stylistic palette beyond the parameters of his debut by incorporating elements of rock, disco, and R&B, thereby broadening the album‚Äôs sonic range and demonstrating increased genre versatility [1]. The sophomore LP produced notable hits such as "Locked Out of Heaven" and "When I Was Your Man," both of which sustained Mars‚Äôs presence on major charts and reinforced his position in the mainstream pop landscape [1].

This record further solidified Mars‚Äôs reputation for songwriting craft and adaptable genre fluency, positioning him for larger-scale productions and a wider array of collaborative opportunities in subsequent projects [1]. The expanded stylistic ambitions of Unorthodox Jukebox thus functioned as a bridge between the melodic pop foundations of the debut and the more deliberately retro and groove-oriented direction that followed [1].

### 24K Magic (2016): concept, recording, and reception

24K Magic marked a conscious return to and reimagining of late twentieth-century R&B, funk, and new jack swing influences, with the album‚Äôs concept framed around a stylized party and rooftop nightlife narrative that Mars described creatively as akin to a "non-existent movie" guiding the record‚Äôs aesthetic [2, 1]. The recording sessions took place during 2015‚Äì2016 at Glenwood Place Studios and emphasized groove, a live-band feel, and careful mixing intended to evoke a 1990s aesthetic while preserving contemporary sonic clarity [2, 1].

Production was principally credited to Shampoo Press & Curl, with additional contributions from the Stereotypes and James Fauntleroy; this collaborative framework supported the album‚Äôs focus on tight arrangements and rhythmic detail [2, 1]. Singles from the album included the title track "24K Magic," "That's What I Like," which reached No. 1 on the Billboard Hot 100, and "Finesse," whose remix featuring Cardi B further amplified the album‚Äôs commercial visibility [2, 1]. Upon release the album debuted at No. 2 on the Billboard 200 and sold approximately 5 million units worldwide, reflecting both strong immediate impact and continued audience interest [2, 1].

Critical response to 24K Magic was generally favorable, with praise directed at its production quality and throwback sound; however, some critics observed a relative reduction in the emotional vulnerability that characterized earlier ballads from Mars [2, 1]. The album‚Äôs industry recognition was significant: it won seven Grammy Awards, including Album of the Year and Best R&B Album, consolidating Mars‚Äôs status as a leading figure in contemporary pop and R&B [2, 1].

## Singles, chart performance and signature hits

Bruno Mars has achieved multiple global hits across his career, registering at least nine Billboard Hot 100 number-one singles and scoring numerous international chart-toppers [1, 2]. These chart accomplishments have been anchored by a set of widely recognized signature singles that span his early ballad-driven breakout through later funk and pop-oriented work; notable examples include "Just the Way You Are", "Grenade", "Locked Out of Heaven", "When I Was Your Man", "Treasure", "24K Magic", and "That's What I Like" [1, 2]. Collectively, these tracks illustrate a trajectory from emotive pop songwriting to retro-inflected, high-production pop and R&B that sustained mainstream appeal across multiple album cycles [1, 2].

High-profile collaborations have amplified Mars's reach and reinforced his mainstream prominence. His prominent feature on Mark Ronson's "Uptown Funk" (2014) became a cultural phenomenon and was commercially dominant, later being cited as Billboard's best-performing song of the 2010s, and his subsequent leadership in Silk Sonic compositions further extended his artistic footprint [1, 2].
